30
 Outcrop data mapped at the Forsmark site suggest that D = 2, a = 3.0 and γ ≈ 4.0.
29

,

31
 The relative density of each fracture set is also indicated in Table 2, according to which the length data can be proportionally assigned to the different sets when constructing discrete fracture networks (see section 3.2).


3.1.2
Present-day and end-glacial stress fields
The present-day in-situ stress state at the Forsmark site has been characterised through comprehensive stress measurement campaigns,
1
 which indicate that the magnitude of principal stress components at the depth between 400 and 600 m tend to follow
32
:

where z is the depth (unit: m), σ
H and σ
h are the maximum and minimum horizontal stresses (unit: MPa), respectively, and σ
v is the vertical stress (unit: MPa). The mean orientation of σ
H is 145° clockwise with respect to North. We assume the pore pressure is hydrostatically distributed in the granitic unit with the water table located at the ground surface. Then, the pore pressure is calculated as p = ρ
w
gz, where ρ
w = 1000 kg/m3 is the water density and g = 9.8 m/s2 is the gravitational acceleration. We define a Biot coefficient of 1.0 so that the effective principal stress components, i.e. σ′
H, σ′
h and σ′
v, can be further derived by subtracting the pore pressure value from the total stress components (Fig. 5
a).
During the repository assessment period, multiple glacial cycles involving ice sheet advance and retreat may happen.
1
 The growth of the continental ice sheet will increase the mechanical load on crustal rocks, leading to elevated vertical and horizontal stresses. During the deglaciation, the ice sheet retreats much faster than the isostatic rebound of the lithosphere, such that the glacially-induced vertical stress diminishes rapidly while the horizontal stress remains for a long period of time. The resulting high stress anisotropy, together with potential pore fluid overpressure, may cause fault destabilisation and trigger earthquakes.
6
 Using the reconstructed Weichselian glacial cycle as a reference condition,
33
 the magnitudes of excess maximum and minimum horizontal stresses that remain after the ice retreat have been estimated as Δσ
H = 11.0 MPa and Δσ
h = 7.6 MPa, respectively, within the upper 1 km depth.
23
 We assume the glacial processes do not significantly alter the stress orientation, i.e. σ
H still trends 145° with respect to North. Furthermore, the glacially-induced residual overpressure (unit: MPa) may follow Δp = 0.0022z for the depth z ≤ 450 m and Δp = 0.0109z-3.91 for the depth z > 450 m.
34
 Thus, the end-glacial effective principal stress components can be further estimated based on the present-day stress state and the excess stress or pore pressure values, as shown in Fig. 5b.


3.1.3
Earthquake scenarios
During the assessment period of up to one million years for the KBS-3 repository, one large earthquake (at most two) having a moment magnitude ≥5 within a 5 km radius around the repository may be expected.
1
 Such an earthquake is considered to be probably triggered by post-glacial processes that destabilise some of the fault zones around the repository.
33
 Based on the established site descriptive model of SKB (Fig. 4),
28
 most fault zones at Forsmark are steeply dipping (80°-90°) and are therefore anticipated to be stable under the present-day/post-glacial reverse faulting stress regimes.
15
 However, a few gently dipping (20°-30°) reverse fault zones, e.g. a shallow fault zone called ZFMA2 (Fig. 4), may potentially be reactivated by post-glacial activities,
14

,

15
 producing large earthquakes threatening the integrity of deposition holes and waste canisters. Thus, in this study, we assume ZFMA2 as the primary fault that accommodates a post-glacial earthquake rupture, whilst all other major fault zones are stable. The ZFMA2 fault zone
1

,

14

,

15

,

28
 has a strike of N80°E, a dip angle of α = 24°, a maximum depth of 1.1 km, a surface trace length of 4.2 km, and a maximum rupture area of 12 km2. According to the previous rupture modelling results in the literature, the ZFMA2 fault tends to accommodate a maximum earthquake moment magnitude of M
w ≈ 5.614,15 with the corresponding seismic moment M
0 calculated as 3.1 × 1017 N m according to equation (10). Thus, we may estimate the average shear displacement ΔU on this seismogenic fault to be ~0.92 m (similar to the values calculated in previous studies
14

,

15
), according to the definition of seismic moment M
0 = GAΔU,
35
 where G = E/[2(1+ν)] is the shear modulus and A is the rupture area. Hereafter, we assume M
w = 5.6 in our study for the potential earthquake at the ZFMA2 fault. We acknowledge that this value might be slightly larger than that predicted from the empirical relationship between moment magnitude and rupture area, which gives M
w = 5.1–5.5 for reverse faulting.
36
 However, it is reasonable to assume a larger M
w as a limiting case
14
 to account for large uncertainties and potential extremes involved in the long-term safety assessment of nuclear waste repository. The hypocentre is assumed at the centre of the fault, i.e. 550 m depth. The planned repository (at the 500 m depth) is in the footwall of ZFMA2 and northwest to the hypocentre (Fig. 4). Note that the considered post-glacial earthquake has a much shallower hypocentre than most earthquakes of tectonic origin; however, shallow earthquakes with hypocentral depth <1 km may still occur, even in the current day.
2





3.2
Model setup and calculation procedure
We model a two-dimensional (2D) square domain of fractured rock (i.e. named as problem domain) with the domain size L = 100 m and the domain centre situated at the 500 m depth (Fig. 5a). We choose the 2D cross-section in the plane of the maximum horizontal stress σ
H and the vertical stress σ
v, where the highest in-plane stress anisotropy is expected given the reverse faulting stress regime (σ
H > σ
h > σ
v) at the Forsmark site, favouring the shear reactivation of secondary fractures. We define a polar coordinate system oriented along the intersection between the primary fault ZFMA2 and the σ
H-σ
v plane (Fig. 6
a). In the context of such a coordinate system, the problem domain is embedded within a larger auxiliary cell (Fig. 6a) of the same material (for the ease of imposing seismic loads) having a radial size of 2L and an angular size of 2L/r
0, where r
0 is the distance between the centre of the problem domain (O′ in Fig. 6a) and the hypocentre (O in Fig. 6a). We run the 2D plane-strain simulation in three stages: (i) the present-day stage, (ii) the end-glacial stage and (iii) the earthquake stage. During the loading stage (i), the present-day effective stress components, i.e. σ′
V and σ′
H (Fig. 5a), are orthogonally imposed to the problem domain (via a ramp to avoid spurious oscillations) with the gravity-induced body forces applied as well, such that the fractured rock reaches an equilibrium under the contemporary static loading. During the loading stage (ii), the end-glacial effective stress components (Fig. 5b) incorporating the excess horizontal stress and residual overpressure are applied to the fractured rock (also via a ramp). Here, we omit the effect of stress history during glacial advance and retreat, considering that fractures tend to be more stabilised when ice sheet grows
33
 and negligible displacements are expected (this is confirmed by our results of very small pre-earthquake slip in section 4). During the loading stage (iii), an earthquake of M
w = 5.6 is assumed to be generated by the reverse faulting of the primary fault ZFMA2 and the resulting displacement field is imposed to the boundaries of the auxiliary cell that encloses the problem domain (Fig. 6a). The auxiliary cell boundaries are also conditioned with a low-reflecting treatment
20
 to suppress unexpected spurious reflection waves. This low-reflecting approach absorbs outgoing waves by imposing a viscous damping force at the model boundary aiming to achieve a perfect impedance match for both P and S waves.
20
 Since σ
H trends 145° with respect to North while the primary fault ZFMA2 has a strike of N80°E, the azimuth angle φ of the σ
H-σ
v plane is thus calculated as 25°. According to the SKB's plan, KBS-3 repository will be built in the footwall of ZFMA227 and northwest to the assumed hypocentre of ZFMA2 (Fig. 4). We explore a number of distance scenarios where the centre of the problem domain is away from the hypocentre (towards North) by r
0 = 400, 500 …, 1600 m (Fig. 6b). We model the crystalline rock embedded with either a single fracture or fracture network. For the single fracture scenario, the fracture centre coincides with the centre of the problem domain and we consider four fracture length values of l = 25, 50, 75 and 100 m, and a range of apparent dip angles (i.e. in-plane dip angles) of β = 0°, 20°, …, 180°. For the fracture network scenario, we generate discrete fracture network realisations (Fig. 7
) obeying the power-law length scaling and orientation/density statistics as described in section 3.1.1. We define the maximum fracture length l
max = 20L = 2000 m; however, it is worth pointing out that the actual maximum length in the problem domain is controlled by the domain size L and thus the selection of l
max is not essential as long as it is much larger than L. We explore two minimum fracture length values of l
min = L/10 = 10 m or L/20 = 5 m with the two cases sharing exactly the same large fractures of l ≥ 10 m (same locations, orientations and lengths) (Fig. 7). It may be expected that the small fractures of l < 10 m tend to accommodate less shear displacements compared to large fractures, but they may still affect the bulk connectivity
37
 and therefore the deformability of the fracture network,
29
 which may need to be examined. We stochastically generate ten sets of fracture network realisations (i.e. ten realisations for each l
min setting) to minimise the potential random effect via configurational averaging. We run numerical simulations using the finite element method-based solver COMSOL Multiphysics,
20
 and the simulation results are reported and analysed in the next section.



4
Simulation results

4.1
Single fracture

Fig. 8
 shows the simulation results of a single secondary fracture with a length of l = 100 m and an apparent dip angle of β = 100° at a distance of r
0 = 400 m to the hypocentre of an earthquake with a moment magnitude of M
w = 5.6. We set a monitoring probe at the fracture centre (where the maximum shear displacement is expected) to record the temporal variation of fracture normal stress, shear stress and shear displacement. The rupture of the primary fault starts at t = 0 s, and the radiated P- and S-waves successively arrive at the fracture, resulting in strong fluctuations of normal and shear stresses. The normal stress in general decreases because the fracture is located in the dilational quadrant during the reverse faulting of the primary fault. The reduced normal stress tends to weaken the shear resistance of the fracture, while the earthquake-induced differential stress attempts to reactive the fracture for shearing. The shear stress exhibits temporary fluctuations during t = 0.12–0.25 s due to the alternating phases of partial slip and total sliding. Then, both the normal and shear stresses stay at zero (i.e. fracture walls are not in contact) during t = 0.25–1.95 s, after which they gradually recover after the passage of earthquake waves. The earthquake-induced shear displacement does not occur instantaneously when the P- or S-wave arrives, but starts to significantly increase when the fracture is reactivated for total sliding (after t = 0.12 s). The shear displacement reaches its maximum value (~11.3 cm) at the earthquake peak time (at t = 1.1 s) and then gradually decreases to an irreversible value after the earthquake (after t = 2.1 s). It can be seen that the shear displacement-time curve exhibits small local fluctuations, which are related to ground vibrations during the earthquake. Furthermore, in Fig. 9
, we show the spatial distribution of shear displacement along this single fracture both at the earthquake peak time and after the earthquake rupture, where a symmetrical displacement profile is observed with the maximum shear displacement in the vicinity of the fracture centre (slight asymmetry is also noticed). We use the maximum value of shear displacement along the entire fracture in the following sensitivity analysis.
We compare the maximum shear displacement of the single fracture (denoted u
s,peak for the peak value at the earthquake peak time and u
s,resid for the residual value after the earthquake rupture) for different values of fracture length l, apparent dip angle β, and fracture-to-hypocentre distance r
0 (Fig. 10
). When r
0 = 400 m (Fig. 10a), the fracture shows very large displacements u
s,peak in many dip angle scenarios, well beyond the safety threshold of u
sc = 5 cm, especially if the fracture length l > 50 m. The displacement also shows a strong dip angle-dependent behaviour with the largest values occur if β ≈ 100° and 20°. Most of the coseismic displacement is reversible and the irreversible component u
s,resid is much smaller than u
s,peak in most dip angle cases. It can be seen that high residual displacement occurs in the case of 60° for which the peak displacement is low; this is because the fracture in this case is less open (i.e. stays in contact) such that frictional resistance significantly restricts the recoverability of shear dislocation. When r
0 increases to 700 m (Fig. 10b), the maximum peak shear displacement u
s,peak reduces significantly. However, the large fracture with l > 50 m may still marginally exceed the safety threshold for certain dip angles, e.g. β ≈ 120°. When r
0 = 1000 or 1300 m, the shear displacement stays below the safety threshold irrespective of the dip angle (Fig. 10c and d). On the other hand, the residual displacement u
s,resid shows a much less sensitivity to the fracture-to-hypocentre distance. We further extract the maximum peak and residual shear displacement among all dip angle scenarios, and examine its variation as a function of the fracture-to-hypocentre distance (Fig. 11
). Clearly, a longer fracture tends to accommodate larger maximum peak shear displacement. Very large shear displacements occur in fractures of l > 50 m located close to the hypocentre, e.g. r
0 = 400 m. The shear displacement drops significantly with the increase of r
0 and becomes below the safety threshold when r
0 > 700 m. The residual displacement seems to be invariant in the distance range of r
0 ≤ 1100 m, and then gradually decreases as the distance exceeds this range.


4.2
Fracture network
We then study the coseismic shear displacements in the realistic fracture networks generated based on the site investigation data of Forsmark (as described in section 3.2). Fig. 12
 illustrates the temporal and spatial variations of the shear displacement distribution in the two fracture networks associated with different minimum fracture lengths of l
min = 5 m and l
min = 10 m and located at a distance of r
0 = 400 m to the hypocentre. Prior to the earthquake rupture (i.e. t = 0 s), the fracture network accommodates almost negligible shearing in the system. Significant shear displacements start to emerge during the earthquake and reaches the maximum values at the earthquake peak time (i.e. t = 1.1 s). It can be seen that only a small proportion of the fracture network is reactivated for sliding and the most sheared segments seem to belong to the interconnected “backbone” of the fracture system. Here, the backbone is a subnetwork of fractures that form connected structures spanning the domain and often dominate the bulk behaviour of the system.
38
 Interestingly, unlike in the single fracture scenario, the dip angle seems to play a less important role and the most reactivated fractures may dip at a wide range of angles. Certain difference is observed regarding the reactivated multi-segment cluster pattern in the two fracture networks with different l
min values. This is because the inclusion of small fractures (5 m ≤ l < 10 m) slightly alters the connectivity structure of the system such that a fracture ≥10 m may be suppressed for shearing in the network of l
min = 10 m (because it is not connected to the backbone) but then become connected to the backbone in the network of l
min = 5 m allowing large displacements. Thus, the network of l
min = 5 m seems to have more reactivated fractures than the network of l
min = 10 m. After the earthquake (t = 2.1 s), some irreversible displacements remain in the system and the two networks show similar patterns. Note that the location of high residual shear displacement does not necessarily corresponds to that of high peak shear displacement. During the passage of seismic waves, some fractures may experience reduced normal stress or even lose the contact between opposing walls (like the single fracture in Fig. 8) such that high peak shear displacement is produced but this displacement can be mostly recovered. On the other hand, the shear of some other fractures may be mainly driven by differential stresses while the fracture walls remain clamped, so that more irreversible component develops. Furthermore, the stress and strain redistribution after the earthquake rupture may also cause some fractures to have the residual displacement larger than the peak displacement (Fig. 12). In Fig. 13
, we further show the spatial distribution of peak and residual shear displacement along a fracture (~66 m long) that exists in both fracture networks. Due to the interconnection with other fractures, the displacement profile of this fracture exhibits a strong discontinuity characteristic that is very different from the elliptical-shaped displacement profile of an isolated fracture (Fig. 9). It can also be seen that the fracture in the network of l
min = 5 m accommodates more shear displacements compared to that in the network of l
min = 10 m, suggesting that the inclusion of small fractures (5 m ≤ l < 10 m) tends to enhance the shear reactivation of large fractures.
We compare the shear displacement field at the earthquake peak time in the fracture networks located at different distances to the hypocentre (Fig. 14
). When r
0 = 400 m, considerable shear displacements beyond the safety threshold of 5 cm are accommodated in the system. With the increase of r
0, the shear displacements become gradually suppressed, especially when r
0 ≥ 700 m. Note that some fractures at a larger distance may become slightly more reactivated for shearing, which is caused by the change of relative orientation between fractures and the earthquake rupture plane with the distance. However, the trend of reduced shear displacement with increased distance in general holds. In Fig. 14, it can also be seen that large shear displacements are mainly accommodated by fractures belonging to the backbone. Some fractures of similar sizes and orientations but not belonging to the backbone show much smaller shear displacements compared to their counterparts inside the backbone. More fractures are reactivated in the network of l
min = 5 m compared to those in the network of l
min = 10 m. In Fig. 15
, we analyse how the maximum peak and residual shear displacement (among all fractures in the network) varies as a function of the distance to the hypocentre. In general, the maximum shear displacement declines with the increase of r
0, and drops below the safety threshold when r
0 ≥ 700 m. The selection of l
min, however, has a minor impact on the maximum shear displacement. This is possibly because the maximum shear displacement is controlled by the large fractures that constitute the core part of the backbone, such that the inclusion of small fractures (e.g. l < 10 m) may introduce more fractures into the backbone (resulting in more reactivated segments) but does not fundamentally change the connectivity architecture. In other words, the inclusion of small fractures may locally change the shear behaviour of some large fractures (as shown in Fig. 13), but the maximum shear displacement is still ruled by the preferentially-oriented, dominant large fractures. It has to be clarified that these small fractures still play an important role in the deformational behaviour of the system as demonstrated by the fact that more shear displacements are accommodated in the network of l
min = 5 m compared to l
min = 10 m. It is just the inclusion of these small fractures tend to have little impact on the maximum value of shear displacement. By comparing Fig. 15 against Fig. 11, it can be seen that the fracture network accommodates larger maximum shear displacements (both peak and residual displacements) than an isolated single fracture, which is because the interconnected fracture network tends to significantly reduce the bulk modulus and enhance the deformability of the rock mass. For the fracture network, the fracture-to-hypocentre safety distance with the maximum shear displacement starts to drop below 5 cm is about 700 m (Fig. 15), which is similar to that for 100 m-long single fractures (Fig. 11). It is noted that the maximum residual displacement of the fracture network exhibits a much stronger sensitivity to the fracture-to-hypocentre distance compared to that of a single fracture, which may be attributed to the interlocking effect in the fracture network making coseismic displacements more difficult to recover.



5
Discussion and conclusions
In this paper, we conducted 2D numerical modelling of the coseismic response of secondary fractures in crystalline rock during large earthquake events. We investigated the scenario of isolated single fractures with various lengths and dip angles located at a range of distances to the hypocentre of an earthquake with a moment magnitude of M
w = 5.6, and observed significant earthquake-induced shear displacement when the fracture is close to the hypocentre. For example, if the fracture-to-hypocentre distance is 400 m, the maximum peak shear displacement of a 100 m-long fracture may exceed 11 cm; however, if the distance is 700 m, the peak displacement is only marginally beyond the safety threshold of 5 cm (Fig. 11). It seems that the maximum peak shear displacement derived in our study is higher than the maximum values reported by Fälth et al. based on their numerical simulations of the Forsmark site (i.e. only ~7 cm for a 150 m-long fracture 200 m away from the primary fault).
14

,

15
 One reason is that different distance metrics were used: in our paper, we measure the distance between the fracture centre and the hypocentre (for the convenience of using the seismic source model), whilst Fälth et al. presented their results based on the distance of the fracture centre to the fault plane. In their model, a fracture 200 m away from the fault plane has a nearest distance of ≥500 m to the hypocentre.
15
 In our simulation, the maximum peak shear displacement at the fracture-to-hypocentre distance of 500 m is ~8 cm, which is in fact very close to that derived by Fälth et al.‘s model. Although our 2D model tends to underestimate the connectivity of 3D systems,
39
 this dimensional effect may be somewhat compromised by the assumption of an in-plane hypocentre in the 2D model (i.e. the normal vectors of 2D fractures are all in the same plane with the hypocentre), which may overestimate the seismic response of the fracture system. This possibly leads to the similar estimates of fracture shear displacement in our 2D model and in Fälth et al.‘s 3D model. In addition to the peak shear displacement, we also emphasise that it is important to characterise the residual component, which can be a critically important parameter for repeated earthquake scenarios. Our results indicate that, if two earthquakes are expected, a fracture-to-hypocentre distance of ≥1200 m may be needed.
It should be admitted that the 2D seismo-mechanical model developed in this paper has some limitations, such as the assumption of an in-plane hypocentre and the simplification of fracture geometries omitting their 3D nature. However, this 2D model is computationally much more efficient than 3D simulation, so that we could further explore the coseismic responses of realistic fracture networks involving highly-intersected fracture sets and fracture length/orientation variations. We found that the earthquake-induced displacement field in a fracture network tends to be dominated by its backbone structure. This phenomenon is consistent with previous studies showing that the shear displacements of a fracture network are often localised into a few dominant fractures or clusters (i.e. interconnected sub-networks) in the system.
40–42
 An interesting finding from our 2D fracture network modelling is that the fracture-to-hypocentre safety distance (beyond which shear displacements stay below 5 cm) is around the same value for single fracture scenarios. Thus, the respect distance estimated for single fractures in previous SKB investigations
7

,

43
 may also be applicable for fracture networks, although more research efforts are needed to confirm this. It is worth pointing out a few other aspects that may also need to be addressed in future modelling efforts. First, fractures in rock may not be planar structures and usually show strong irregularities, undulations and heterogeneities,
44
 which may have important impacts on the shear displacement behaviour.
45–47
 Second, the constitutive behaviour of fractured rocks may also be much more complex in natural systems,
35
 which may involve brittle failure in intact rocks (rather than obeying linear elasticity) and rate- and state-dependent friction along rough discontinuities (rather than obeying Coulomb's law). Third, realistic (or even site-specific) source time functions may be used to achieve more accurate prediction of the coseismic displacement field; however, high-resolution characterisation of detailed source time functions of natural earthquakes may not be a trivial task, which may reply on comprehensive recordings of strong ground motion near the causative fault with broadband seismometers.
21
 Furthermore, static stress change may occur following the mainshock and play a role in coseismic triggering of nearby fractures,
9
 the analysis of which may require a direct modelling of the rupture process along the seismogenic fault.
To conclude, we observed that the coseismic shear displacement of an isolated secondary fracture tends to be strongly dependent on the fracture length and dip angle, while the coseismic displacement of a highly-intersected fracture system is more governed by the connectivity structure of the network. Profound coseismic shear displacement occurs when the secondary fracture or fracture network is close to the hypocentre and located in the dilational quadrant of the primary seismogenic fault, where significantly reduced normal stress and shear resistance may occur along the fracture. However, the earthquake-induced shear displacement decreases drastically with the increased distance to the hypocentre and if the distance is more than 700 m, the coseismic shear displacement of fractures with lengths ≤100 m tends to stay below the safety threshold of 5 cm, above which the shear failure of waste canisters may occur. If two repeated earthquakes would occur, a distance of no less than 1200 m may be needed to avoid the accumulated displacement exceeding the safety threshold. The observation and analysis of coseismic responses of secondary fracture systems as presented in this paper have important implications for the long-term safety assessment of planned nuclear waste repositories in crystalline rocks in many countries worldwide.

Introduction
Fault reactivation is associated with (incremental) slip displacement along existing natural faults after a long period of inactivity (e.g
1
), and is evaluated because slip displacement may cause an increase of fault permeability, earthquakes and damage to wells. An increase of permeability along fault planes may cause leakage of potentially contaminated or economically valuable fluids and gases out of a subsurface reservoir. This is a concern during production from oil and gas reservoirs, in particular in case of Enhance Oil Recovery (EOR) operations when injecting water, gas or steam. The same concerns are present when disposing water or CO2 in (depleted) subsurface reservoirs. Recorded earthquakes in areas with such activities may be induced or triggered.
2

,

3
 Earthquakes generate ground velocity and ground acceleration that could damage houses and other infrastructure (e.g.
4–6
). Finally, slip displacement caused by fault reactivation may deform injection or production wells to such an extent that they become inoperable. This may again result in leakage of tubulars (loss of containments), inability to re-enter the well for maintenance operations, or complete failure.

,

In the 1990's, the slip tendency was used to explain the episodic migration of fluids in the Earth's crest by an increase of fault permeability due to reactivation of faults (earthquakes) on a geological time scale.

Facilitated by the increasing computer capacity since the 1990's, two-dimensional finite-element (FE) studies on simplified, but realistic geological structures were conducted to assess fault reactivation as an indicator for potential leakage of CO2 out of geological storage sites,

 All these studies show a much more complex distribution of shear stress along the fault plane compared to analyses based on an analytical Mohr circle evaluation. The 2D analyses over the last two decades make it clear that the subsurface structure and, in particular, the reservoir offset have a prominent influence on fault reactivation caused by reservoir depletion or injection.
In this study, the results of a conventional Mohr-circle evaluation is compared to the results that are obtained from an equivalent 2D finite-element analyses, and advice is formulated on the appropriate use of both methods. Also, some modelling requirements are formulated when assessing fault reactivation, particularly when a 3D FE model is used. In chapter 2, the Mohr-circle evaluation and the two-dimensional finite-element modelling approach are briefly summarised. In Chapter 3, fault reactivation is evaluated using both methods for reservoirs without offset, considering a depleting gas reservoir as situated in the Northern part of The Netherlands. The influence of the fault dip angle, the horizontal in-situ stress and Poisson's ratio, which influences the stress-path coefficient, are highlighted. The impact of the reservoir offset on the value of the depletion pressure that causes fault reactivation is discussed in Chapter 4 using finite-element techniques only. The minimum element size for meaningful (3D) finite-element analyses on fault reactivation is determined in Chapter 5 by showing the influence of the element size on the computed depletion pressure required for fault reactivation.

2.2
Finite-element modelling assumptions
A reservoir-fault configuration representative of the gas fields in the Northern Netherlands is selected for the comparison of a Mohr-circle analysis and a two dimensional finite-element analysis. The Base Case configuration is comprised of a horizontal, 215 m thick depleting gas reservoir at a depth of 2830 m, which is intersected by a fault dipping under 65° (Fig. 2
a). In the sensitivity analyses of this study, reservoir offset is varied by keeping the top of the foot wall reservoir at the same depth and adjusting the top of the hanging reservoir. The reservoir thickness is varied by adjusting the bottom of the depleting reservoir on both fault blocks by an equal amount.

Fig. 2b shows the pore pressure in the fault as a function of depth under initial and depleted reservoir conditions. The dark-blue line indicates the initial pore pressure and shows an over-pressured reservoir and aquifer compared to the pore pressure in the overburden. The green vertical bars on the left-hand side of the graph indicate the depth interval of the depleting reservoir formations. The gas pressure gradient of 0.018 kPa/m is based on the gas density in the reservoir formations, with an initial pressure of 35.2 MPa at the gas-water contact at 2995 m depth. The pore pressure gradient in the aquifer below the reservoir is in pressure communication with the gas reservoir and is 11.66 kPa/m. A fresh water gradient of 10.0 kPa/m without overpressure is assumed in the overburden. The gas column causes a step-change in pore pressure across the top-seal due to the low density of the gas. The fault follows the equal and uniform pore pressure reduction in the foot wall and hanging wall reservoir (

The total vertical stress gradient is 21.4 kPa/m and is based on density log data representative of the Northern Netherlands. A finite-element model generator was built for the DIANA software
39
 to efficiently evaluate a large number of geometrical configurations with different thicknesses for various formations as outlined in Fig. 2a. The model generator identifies eight different horizontal formation layers, four on each side of the fault, that can be assigned thickness, density and mechanical failure properties independently. Thickness of the eight layers was assigned in correspondence with Fig. 2a, while reservoir offset was modelled by adjusting only the thickness of the overburden layer in the hanging wall. Reservoir thickness was evaluated by adjusting the thickness of the hanging wall and foot wall reservoir formations simultaneously.
Linear plain strain continuum elements are used for all eight formation layers with identical linear-elastic properties (Young's modulus E = 10 GPa, Poisson's ratio ν = 0.25). This means that the shear modulus G is 4.0 GPa. Linear, one-dimensional interface elements are used to simulate fault slip behaviour (Fig. 3
b). The normal and shear stress along the interface elements adheres to an elastic-perfect-plastic relationship with differential displacements

The length of the interface elements is 1 m over the reservoir interval in order to accurately calculate the development of critical stress conditions in cases that include a reservoir offset. The size of the linear continuum elements next to the interface elements have the same height and increase in length towards the boundaries of the model. The fault zone and the four formations on each side can be recognised by the small element region in the middle of the model in Fig. 3. The top surface of the model has a zero stress boundary condition, while the normal displacements of the nodes along the two vertical sides and the bottom of the model are prohibited. The finite-element analysis comprise of a two-dimensional plane strain static analysis, in which reservoir depletion is simulated as pore pressure loading, applied in 30 increments of −1 MPa. Compressive stress is positive in this paper.



3
Reactivations of faults intersecting reservoirs without offset
In section 3.1, the Base-case configuration, without reservoir offset as described in section 2.2, is evaluated for fault reactivation using the Mohr circle approach and in section 3.2 using the finite-element model.

3.1
The Mohr-circle analysis results
A Mohr-circle analysis was conducted for the stress condition on the fault plane in the reservoir interval at 2875 m depth under initial and depleted reservoir conditions. The green Mohr-circle in Fig. 4
 represents the initial effective stress condition at this depth and is determined by the vertical effective stress of 26.5 MPa and the minimum effective horizontal stress of 11.0 MPa (see section 2.2 for the stress gradients). The green dot on the green Mohr circle reflects the initial effective normal and shear stress condition on a fault plane dipping under 65° with a horizontal plane. The initial SCU is 0.63 for the low-friction case with a friction angle of 10° and a cohesion stress of 7 MPa (black solid line), while the SCU is 0.71 for the base case with a friction angle of 31° (black dashed line).
The blue point on the blue Mohr-circle in Fig. 4 represents the fault stress condition at 2875 m depth after 19.9 MPa reservoir depletion and is calculated using equations (8) and (9) and a Poisson's ratio of 0.25 for the horizontal stress-path coefficient in equation (4). The vertical stress path coefficient is assumed to be zero. In the low-friction case, the SCU is 1 because the stress condition is on the Mohr-Coulomb shear failure line, implying that the fault reactivates (starts slipping). The SCU is 0.80 after 19.9 MPa depletion in the normal-friction case. Similar results have been obtained by other authors previously (e.g,
38
).


3.2
Impact of Poisson's ratio
The normal effective and shear stress condition on the fault plane at 2875 m depth progresses with increasing reservoir depletion along the path indicated by the light-green line in Fig. 5
a. Every subsequent marker along the stress path indicates an incremental depletion of 5 MPa. The light-green line for a Poisson's ratio 
ν
 of 0.25 intersects the Mohr-Coulomb failure line for the low-friction case after 19.9 MPa reservoir depletion. The stress path is steeper for smaller values for Poisson's ratio in accordance with equations (4), (8) and (9), and requires a smaller reservoir depletion to intersect the failure line and cause onset of fault slip (slightly more than 10 MPa if a Poisson's ratio of 0.05 is assumed). Onset of fault slip is not reached up to a reservoir depletion of 30 MPa if Poisson's ratio is increased to a value larger than 0.30 for the low-friction case. For a friction angle of 31° (dashed black line in Fig. 5a), the Mohr-circle analysis only predicts fault reactivation for a reservoir depletion smaller than 30 MPa if Poisson's ratio is smaller than 0.25. The strong influence of Poisson's ratio on the reservoir depletion that causes fault reactivation is shown in Fig. 5b. The vertical axis is truncated at 30 MPa, because this is close to the maximum possible reservoir depletion.

3.2.1
Impact of fault inclination and minimum horizontal stress uncertainty
The initial stress condition, and thereby the starting point of the stress path, is influenced by the fault dip angle as indicate in Fig. 6
a. No shear stress is present on a vertical fault plane (dip angle 90°) under the assumed initial stress condition. The initial stress condition on a fault plane moves along the Mohr circle in clock-wise direction with decreasing dip angle and reaches the maximum initial shear stress under a dip angle of 45° (green markers are plotted every 5°). It is noted that the stress paths are also influenced by the fault dip angle: the length of the stress path up to 30 MPa reservoir depletion is shorter for steeper fault planes. As a consequence, a fault dipping under 65° starts slipping after slightly more than 10 MPa reservoir depletion if Poisson's ratio of the reservoir formation is 0.05, while a fault dipping under 80° will remain in the elastic regime up to 30 MPa reservoir depletion in the same reservoir. This is also reflected in Fig. 5b, which shows that no fault slip is predicted within 30 MPa depletion for faults dipping steeper than about 75°.
The impact of the minimum horizontal stress on the stress path and the onset of fault slip is shown in Fig. 6b. The solid green circle represents the Base Case with a minimum effective horizontal stress of 16.0 kPa/m (11.0 MPa at 2875 m depth), whereas the smaller, dashed circle represents the case with a minimum horizontal stress gradient of 16.6 kPa/m and the largest, dotted circle the case with a value of 15.4 kPa/m. It is seen that the reservoir depletion required to cause fault reactivation increases with decreasing size of the Mohr circle (decreasing deviatoric stress, see also e.g.
36
).



3.3
Finite-element analysis results
The Base Case is also evaluated using the general purpose DIANA finite-element software that is commercially available.
39
 The model with interface elements representing the fault, the loading and the boundary conditions are described in section 2.2. Fig. 7
a is identical to Fig. 2b and shows the prescribed pore pressure distribution for different depletion levels. The reservoir pressure is assumed to be equal in both fault blocks and is reduced in steps of 1 MPa from 35.2 to 5.2 MPa (reservoir depletion of 30 MPa). The evolution of the normal effective stress is shown in Fig. 7b and the evolution of the shear stress in Fig. 7c. Negative values for the shear stress indicate a down ward pointing shear stress on the foot wall formations, thereby confirming the normal faulting environment. The Shear Capacity Utilisation in Fig. 7d is calculated from the normal and shear stress in Fig. 7b/c using equation (7), while assuming the low-friction case. Fault reactivation occurs if SCU = 1 in any interface element and is found at the same reservoir depletion of 19.9 MPa as in the Mohr circle analysis (section 3.1). Note that the fault SCU reaches a value of 1 almost at the same reservoir depletion over the entire reservoir depth interval. An inelastic relative slip displacement across the fault develops, adhering to the assumed elastic-perfect-plastic fault slip relationship, if depletion is increased beyond 19.9 MPa as shown in Fig. 7e. A maximum Relative Slip Displacement (RSD) of 0.079 m is calculated after 30 MPa depletion. Unlike the Mohr-circle analysis, the SCU remains 1 once the Mohr-Coulomb shear failure criterion is met, in accordance with the assumed plasticity rule in the finite-element model (section 2.2).

Fig. 8
a shows that the finite-element solution (green markers) exactly follows the same stress path as the analytical approach (light-green line) until the onset of fault slip occurs after 19.9 MPa reservoir depletion. At this depletion level, the maximum SCU reaches 1 (Fig. 8b). Upon further reservoir depletion, the stress path departs from the linear-elastic trend line and starts following the red Mohr-Coulomb failure line, adhering to the requirement that stress conditions above the failure line cannot exist. Fig. 8 also shows the shear failure line and SCU development corresponding with the normal-friction case, with a friction angle of 31° and negligible cohesion. It is seen that fault reactivation does not occur even if reservoir depletion would reach 30 MPa, because the stress path runs virtually parallel to the failure line.



4
Discussion
The Mohr-circle analysis based on the low-friction case shows the strong influence of Poisson's ratio on the depletion pressure that causes onset of fault slip. A smaller Poisson's ratio implies a smaller lateral expansion of the depleting reservoir formation, and therefore a smaller increase of the horizontal effective stress due to reservoir depletion. This explains the steeper stress path and the smaller depletion pressure required to cause onset of fault slip. The normal-friction case shows that a realistic value for the friction angle in combination with a realistic value for Poisson's ratio does not lead to shear failure along a 65° dipping fault plane. Fault reactivation along more steeply dipping faults is even less likely. A Mohr-circle analysis for the Groningen gas field, where the majority of the faults are dipping under an angle between 75 and 80°, would conclude that fault slip and induced seismicity is unlikely.
The Mohr-circle and finite-element analysis provide exactly the same reservoir depletion pressure for fault reactivation if a linear-elastic and homogenous subsurface is assumed, in which the fault does not offset the depleting reservoir. Identical results are also found when varying the fault dip and azimuth angle, Poisson's ratio and the initial stress conditions. Young's modulus does not have any impact on the stress distribution along the fault, because it does not appear in the stress-path coefficients in equation (3). The analytically derived stress path for uniaxial compacting reservoirs is accurate until the shear failure condition is met and onset of fault slip occurs. Under these assumptions, a Mohr-circle analysis is the preferred method for the calculation of fault reactivation, because it provides more insight into the response of the subsurface to reservoir depletion (or inflation), but also because it is much faster to evaluate, thereby facilitating the evaluation of uncertainties in all modelling parameters.
8




5
Reactivation of faults intersecting reservoirs with offset
The finite-element model is used to evaluate the depletion pressure that causes fault reactivation in reservoirs with offset. To this end, the overburden thickness of the hanging wall is increased, while keeping the depth of the foot wall reservoir and all other modelling parameters the same as in the Base Case (section 2.2). The results for the case with 80 m reservoir offset is discussed in detail in section 5.1, while the fault reactivation pressures for a large number of reservoir offsets between −300 (up-thrown) and +500 m (down-thrown) are presented in section 5.2. The results are compared with the Mohr-circle evaluation for the case without offset.

5.1
Case study: 80 m reservoir offset
The stress distribution along the fault plane is discussed for the case in which the hanging wall reservoir is 80 m deeper than the foot wall reservoir. Similar to the Base Case, reservoir depletion is equal in both fault blocks and is increased in steps of 1 MPa up to 30 MPa.

Fig. 9
a shows that the fault is exposed to reservoir depletion over a larger depth interval due to the fault offset. This reflects the assumption that the fault pore pressure follows the pressure of adjacent formation. The normal effective stress (Fig. 9b) is significantly smaller over the juxtaposed reservoir interval where the fault is exposed to reservoir depletion on both sides, compared to the intervals that are exposed to depletion in either the foot wall or hanging wall reservoir only. The shear stress and SCU distribution (Fig. 9c and d respectively) show peak values at the top of the hanging wall reservoir and at the bottom of the foot wall reservoir. The small peak value at the top of the hanging wall is caused by the larger gas pressure in the foot wall reservoir compared to the hydrostatic pore pressure in the overburden above the hanging wall. Onset of fault slip occurs when SCU = 1 at the bottom of the foot wall after 5.9 MPa reservoir depletion slightly before fault slip starts at the top of the hanging wall. Furthermore, it is noticed that the shear stress and SCU is reducing due to reservoir depletion at the top of the foot wall and at the bottom of the hanging wall. This means that the fault stress condition becomes less critical at these locations due to reservoir depletion. The relative slip displacement in Fig. 9e is negligible and elastic (recoverable) until onset of fault slip occurs after 5.9 MPa reservoir depletion.

Fig. 10
b shows the stress paths at different locations along the fault plane due to increasing reservoir depletion. The locations are indicated in Fig. 10a, which also shows the SCU distribution along the fault plane after 0 and 6 MPa reservoir depletion (similar to Fig. 9d). After 6 MPa reservoir depletion, a small slip patch has appeared at the bottom of the foot wall reservoir where SCU = 1. This is confirmed by the position of the second marker of the purple line in Fig. 10b, which lies on the Mohr-Coulomb failure line specified by a cohesion of 7 MPa and a friction angle of 10°. The (red) stress path at the top of the hanging wall (at −2910 m) reaches the shear failure criterion at a slightly larger depletion pressure, as the third marker (representing 7 MPa depletion).
The other three stress paths in Fig. 10b are significantly less critical. In particular, the green and blue stress paths, which represents the points at the top and bottom of the reservoir interval at −2830 m and −3125 m depth respectively, develop a reverse shear stress condition with increasing reservoir depletion. This is also seen by the changing sign of the shear stress in Fig. 9c. A positive shear stress means that an upward shear stress is exerted on the foot wall formations. Also, the yellow stress path for the point at 2875 m depth is less critical compared to the stress path for the case without offset shown in Fig. 5a (light-green line for Poisson's ratio 
ν
 = 0.25).

Fig. 11
 shows the increasing total length of the slip patches (red line) and the maximum slip displacement (yellow line) with increasing reservoir depletion. Two slip patches develop along the fault plane after the onset of fault slip at 5.9 MPa reservoir depletion. This is recognised by the two intervals where SCU = 1 (light-blue line) in Fig. 9d. The total length of the two slip patches accelerates with incremental depletion until they merge after about 12 MPa depletion, covering the entire juxtaposed interval. Thereafter, the slip patch extension continues at a slower pace with incremental depletion over the shallower part of the foot wall, and the deeper part of the hanging wall. Furthermore, Fig. 11 shows a gradual increase of the maximum relative (inelastic) slip displacement up to 0.25 m after 30 MPa depletion (see also Fig. 9e).


5.2
Fault re-activation as a function of reservoir offset
In a similar way, the stress and slip distribution along the fault plane has been evaluated for a large number of cases with a reservoir offset between −300 (up-thrown) and +500 m (down-thrown). Note, however, that the initial stress conditions are the same in all cases, reflecting a normal faulting regime. For each case, the reservoir depletion that causes onset of fault slip has been determined assuming a friction angle of 10° and a cohesion of 7 MPa (the low-friction case).

Fig. 12
 shows the reservoir depletion as a function of the normalised reservoir offset, which is defined as the absolute reservoir offset divided by the reservoir thickness (215 m in the Base Case). Fig. 12 shows that fault reactivation occurs at substantially smaller depletion pressures in cases with offset compared to the Base Case without offset. A Mohr-circle evaluation represents the case without offset, in which fault reactivation occurs after 19.9 MPa reservoir depletion. Fault reactivation occurs at a decreasing depletion pressure with increasing offset of the hanging wall. The smallest depletion pressure is found if the normalised reservoir offset is 1, which is if the offset is equal to the reservoir thickness. The depletion pressure increases again for an offset larger than the reservoir thickness. The depletion pressure required to cause fault reactivation is also significantly smaller than found in the Mohr-circle analysis is cases with negative offset, where the hanging wall is shallower than the foot wall. For the assumed fault orientation, fault strength and initial stress condition it is found that reactivation may be only 30% (5.9 MPa) of the reservoir depletion calculated using the Mohr-circle analysis (19.9 MPa) depending on the reservoir offset.


5.3
The influence of reservoir thickness on fault re-activation in depleting reservoirs with offset
The series of analyses for a reservoir thickness of 215 m discussed in section 4.2 were repeated for a thickness of 165 m and 265 m. This range largely covers the thickness of the depleting reservoir formations across the Groningen gas field. The absolute reservoir offset was varied for each series of analyses such that the normalised reservoir offset covered the range between −1 (up-thown) and +2 (down-thrown). All other modelling parameters were taken to be the same as in Chapter 4 (i.e. fault dip and azimuth angle are 65 and 90° respectively).

Fig. 12 shows that the depletion pressure required to cause onset of fault slip is dependent on the normalised reservoir offset (absolute offset divided by reservoir thickness), but not on the reservoir thickness. This implies that the incremental normal and shear stress distribution along the fault plane induced by reservoir depletion scales proportionally with the reservoir thickness. Also, the length of the slip patch and the (maximum) slip displacement scale proportional with the reservoir thickness.
41





6
The importance of a small element size
In this section, the element size requirement for an accurate computation of the reservoir depletion pressure that causes fault reactivation in finite-element analyses is evaluated. The shear stress concentration at the top and bottom of the foot wall and hanging wall reservoir formations require sufficiently small elements to be captured accurately. In particular, for three-dimensional finite-element analyses it is important to balance meaningful results (small element sizes) with computational effort (large element sizes). To illustrate this, a case describing a 140 m thick reservoir with a bounding fault dipping under 65° is evaluated (Fig. 13
) using an element size ranging from 0.5 m to 50 m. So far, results are obtained using an element size of 1 m along the depleting reservoir, whereas it is not uncommon that only a few elements over the reservoir height are used in 3D analyses.
28,32,42,43


The model in Fig. 13 has different elastic properties for the reservoir layers, the top seal and overburden formations, while the fault friction angle is 31° and the cohesion is 0 MPa. The reservoir is situated in a normal stress regime with the total minimum horizontal stress being 72% of the vertical stress. Pore pressure is slightly over-pressured at 11.66 kPa/m, with a gas pressure gradient in the reservoir of 1.8 kPa/m, similar to specified in section 2.2. The objective is to determine the maximum element size that allows for an accurate assessment of the depletion pressure that causes fault reactivation. The 140 m reservoir formations in Fig. 13 are evaluated using an element size of 50, 20, 10, 5, 2, 1 and 0.5 m in the vertical direction. The horizontal size of the elements is also adjusted to maintain an aspect ratio of less than 2 close to the fault.

Fig. 14
a shows that the element size does not influence the pore pressure loading on the fault. In this particular case, reservoir pore pressure is decreased from about 35 MPa to 5 MPa in the foot wall reservoir only (right-hand side of the fault). The normal effective stress on the fault over the reservoir interval (Fig. 14b) increases due to depletion. However, the largest element size of 50 m only captures the gradient and absolute value over about a third of the reservoir height. The shear stress concentration at the top and bottom of the reservoir interval (Fig. 14c) is not well captured for an element size larger than 10 m. The peak value increases with smaller element size, but the difference in shear stress can be as large as 12 MPa. The Shear Capacity Utilisation (Fig. 14d) shows onset of fault slip at 9.0 MPa reservoir depletion for an element size smaller or equal than 2 m (see also Fig. 15
). For a larger element size, onset of fault slip is found at an increasing depletion pressure, while no fault slip is calculated in case of an element size of 50 m.


7
Discussion
The stress distribution along the fault plane can be determined by superposition of the incremental stress caused by depletion in both the foot wall and hanging wall. In a normal faulting environment, this leads to an increase of shear stress at the top of the hanging wall reservoir and at the bottom of the foot wall reservoir (Figs. 9 and 14). This study shows that fault reactivation occurs at these locations. The peak values in the shear stress distribution vanish in the absence of reservoir offset. This explains why a substantially larger reservoir depletion is required to cause fault reactivation in cases without offset. The main reason why a Mohr-circle evaluation estimates a depletion pressure which is too high is because the evaluation does not consider reservoir offset and is not conducted for the most critical point along the fault plane. The reason why a normalised reservoir offset of 1 requires the smallest reservoir depletion to cause fault reactivation is because the shear stress peak at the top of the hanging wall coincides with the shear stress peak at the bottom of the foot wall.
On the other hand, the shear stress is reduced at the top foot wall and at the bottom of the hanging wall. A similar shear stress distribution is found along the vertical edges of a rectangular depleting reservoir.
44
 This reduced shear stress provides a barrier for fault slip propagation outside the depth interval of the fault that is exposed to reservoir depletion (Fig. 9c/d). This is also found in other studies.
45


Some of the modelling assumptions in the finite-element analysis influence the magnitude of the shear stress concentration and thereby the depletion pressure that causes fault reactivation. The discontinuous pore pressure between the depleting and the non-depleting reservoir formations across the fault can be expected to be more gradual when incorporating formation and fault permeability as shown by Zbinden et al.
34
 Also, the normal and shear stiffness of the interface elements influence the computed shear stress concentration along the fault plane and can be used to account for the width of the fault core and damage zone.
46
 Despite these modelling assumption, this study demonstrates that the shear stress along a fault plane is not uniformly changing over the depletion interval when the reservoir is offset along a fault plane or when the depletion occurs on one side of the fault only. For these cases, a Mohr-circle evaluation based on stress-path coefficients as outlined in the introduction provides an underestimation of the depletion pressure that causes fault reactivation. The observed induced seismicity in the Groningen gas field
41,45,46
 and the inability of a Mohr circle analysis to predict fault reactivation provides further support for this finding.

Fig. 12 demonstrates that the normal and shear stress distribution scales with the reservoir thickness for given normalised reservoir offset. This implies that the minimum size for linear elements to accurately calculate of the onset of fault slip can also be scaled to the reservoir thickness as considered in section 5. The results therefore suggests that 3D geomechanical models with a vertical element size of more than about 2% of the reservoir height are not able to accurately capture fault reactivation in cases with offset. An element size of more than 30% of the reservoir thickness may even miss the possible onset of fault slip.


8
Conclusions
This study demonstrates that a Mohr-circle analysis under-estimates the risk of induced fault reactivation in depleting reservoirs that contain faults with offset. Practically, this statement holds for any mapped fault, as formation offset is a prerequisite for the recognition of faults through seismic interpretation. The explanation for this under-estimation is found in the fact that a Mohr-circle evaluation does not consider the most critically-stressed fault location, which are located at the top of the hanging wall and at the bottom of the foot wall reservoir in a normally stressed environment. The case with an offset equal to the reservoir thickness constitutes the most susceptible configuration for fault reactivation and requires the smallest reservoir depletion. We also conclude that reservoir depletion on one side of the fault does not constitute the worst-case scenario as explained by cases with a very large (positive or negative) offset (see Fig. 12). In stead, a reservoir offset equal to the reservoir thickness and depletion on both sides of the fault constitutes the worst-case scenario. In the current study, the required pressure drop or depletion is only 30% of the reservoir depletion computed using a Mohr-circle evaluation representing the case without offset. A Mohr-circle evaluation should therefore be avoided in hazard analysis as it provides a non-conservative result.
The occurrence of shear stress concentration at the top and bottom of depleting reservoirs also imposes a requirement for the minimum element size in 2D and 3D finite-element evaluation. This study shows that the normal and shear stress distribution along the fault plane scales with reservoir thickness for given normalised reservoir offset. A vertical element size of more than about 2% over the reservoir height is not able to accurately capture fault reactivation in cases with offset. An element size of more than 30% of the reservoir thickness may even overlook the onset of fault slip.
Text.19:
1
Introduction
The potential for activation of faults and fractures in low permeability argillaceous (compacted) claystone or shale is relevant to a number of geo-energy activities, such as to ensure caprock integrity of geologic sequestration sites,
1
 for improved stimulation and production from shale gas reservoirs,
2–4
 and for safe permanent geologic disposal of nuclear waste in argillaceous clay formations.
5
 The main concern associated with nuclear waste disposal is the potential for repository induced or natural perturbations to create permeable flow paths through the initially impermeable host rock barrier. If such a flow path is created and remains open permanently, it could provide a transport path for radionuclides if released from a waste package.
In geologic nuclear waste disposal in argillaceous clay, fault activation may be caused by repository-scale thermally-driven stress changes and so-called thermal pressurization.
6

,

7
 Thermal pressurization is a process of pressure increase by thermal expansion of pore-fluids trapped within pores of the low permeability host rock (Fig. 1
). If not carefully managed by an appropriate repository design, the repository temperature and associated thermal pressurization could become so high that it could potentially cause hydraulic fracturing or shear activation of existing fractures and minor faults.
8
 The impact of such thermal pressurization with respect to shear activation is two-fold in that it can (1) reduce the effective stress and shear strength of fractures (or faults), and (2) increase the shear stress across fractures (or faults) (Fig. 1). Other potential causes of fault activation or fracturing of a low permeability host rock include gas generation within the engineered barrier system of a repository
9
 or seismic motion from a distant earthquake.
10
 Distant earthquakes produce dynamic strains that give rise to pore pressure changes
11
 that could potentially trigger shear slip on faults that are stressed near instability.
12


In this article we present results from an international modeling comparison study of controlled fault activation experiments that were conducted in Opalinus Clay at the Mont Terri Laboratory, Switzerland.
13–15
 The study was part of the international collaborative project DECOVALEX-2019 (from 2015 to 2019) where it was denoted Task B.
16
 While this article aims at synthesizing some of the most important results and findings related to interpretative modeling of observed hydromechanical fault behavior, a complete coverage of all the results and model comparisons are reported in Graupner et al.
17
 In the next section of this article, we introduce the DECOVALEX-2019 Task B, the international modeling teams and their models. This is followed by results from an initial benchmark model exercise, before presenting the modeling of two controlled fault activation experiments at Mont Terri. We end with a discussion on the results and conclusions with implications to nuclear waste disposal in argillaceous clay formations.


2
DECOVALEX-2019 TASK B description
The objectives of DECOVALEX-2019, Task B, were to develop, compare and validate models for fault hydromechanical behavior in argillaceous clay (shale) formations, relevant to deep underground nuclear waste disposal.
16

,

17
 The main task was to develop models and perform interpretative modeling of water-injection fault activation experiments at the Mont Terri Laboratory. The model simulations focused on (1) one experiment activating a discontinuity (fracture or minor fault) within the damage zone of the Main Fault, and (2) a second experiment activating discontinuities close to the core of the Main Fault. The experimental data from these fault activation experiments consist of flow, pore pressure and three-dimensional fault displacement continuously monitored at an injection borehole and a monitoring borehole located a few meters away.
In DECOVALEX-2019, Task B, the modeling teams were tasked to conduct modeling in three steps of increasing complexity:

•
Step 1 - Model inception and benchmarking using a simplified setup


•
Step 2 - Modeling fault activation experiment in the fault damage zone, and


•
Step 3 - Modeling fault activation experiment at the fault core



The Step 1 benchmarking involved modeling of a single discontinuity, a simplified version of the Step 2 fault activation experiment, whereas Step 3 involved modeling of several connected discontinuities. Here we use the term discontinuity as a general term that includes fractures, faults (fractures or discontinuities with previous shear offset), bedding planes, as well as interfaces between rock units, such as the discontinuity that may exist between a fault core and surround rock.
The objective of Step 1 was to provide modeling teams with a well-defined benchmark exercise considering a detailed specification of the discontinuity plane, including a pre-defined hydromechanical model with clearly specified material properties and model geometry. This was intended as a model inception for the modeling teams to familiarize themselves with the problem and allow for necessary model developments and testing. During the course of the three-year project (2015–2019), more benchmarks were defined, including uncoupled flow problems that were used to help the teams identifying technical issues with their models.
17


Step 2 and 3 were focused on interpretative modeling of the actual field experiments and in addition to providing model valuation they are modeled to advance our understanding of fault activation processes based on measured data. Both of these experiments involved activation of discontinuities at the scale of a few meters, within the Main Fault (Fig. 2
). The activation experiments were carried out by water injection into isolated borehole sections (2.4 m in length) that were intersected by a number of discontinuities of various types and orientations. These boreholes were drilled vertically downward from a tunnel in the Mont Terri Laboratory, with the borehole test sections far enough away from the tunnel to avoid any related stress perturbation. Stepwise increases in borehole pressure were imposed until the pressure was sufficiently high to cause an activation of one or several of the discontinuities. Injection rate, fluid pressure and three-dimensional borehole deformations were measured at high frequency with a specialized borehole monitoring equipment.
13

,

14

,

18
 A protocol for measurements with this borehole monitoring equipment was described in Guglielmi et al.
18
 The protocol was presented as an International Society of Rock Mechanics (ISRM) suggested method for step-rate injection method for fracture in-situ properties (SIMFIP). The two fault activation experiments are further described in Sections 5 and 6 related to the Step 2 and Step 3 modeling activities.


3
Modeling teams and numerical simulators
Seven modeling teams of the DECOVALEX-2019 initiative participated in analyzing the experimental data using different modeling approaches and computer codes (Table 1
). The fault activation models can be categorized into models representing a fault by an interface and models representing a fault by finite thickness solid elements. In all models, the fault geometry is simplified as a plane cutting the entire model. The differences between interface and solid element representations of faults are conceptually described in Fig. 3
. That is, a fracture or fault represented by an interface or discontinuity explicitly models normal and shear displacements as a function of changes in effective normal and shear stress.
13

,

19–24
 Transmissivity for fracture flow can be directly related to fracture aperture through the parallel plate flow assumption.
25

,

26
 For a finite thickness solid element representation of a fracture or fault, a fracture aperture is considered implicitly within the element thickness and equivalent properties are calculated to represent fracture stiffness and flow transmissivity.
27–32
 This includes equivalent elastic modulus and permeability, both of which may involve anisotropy through constitutive models. Another variant is the linking of mechanical codes representing fractures or faults with interface elements to porous media flow in finite thickness elements.
33

,

34


A diverse set of numerical simulators (or computer codes) where applied in this study (Table 1). The TOUGH-FLAC simulator
35

,

36
 used by KIGAM and LBNL is based on sequential coupling of the TOUGH2 multiphase flow simulator
37
 with the FLAC3D geomechanical simulator.
38
 TOUGH-FLAC has previously been extensively applied for modeling fault activation associated with carbon sequestration,
39

,

40
 stimulation of shale gas, and geothermal reservoirs,
41

,

42
 and during production from hydrocarbon reservoirs.
43
 For the finite thickness fault element approach, an anisotropic elasto-plastic model is used such that shear failure occurs along the fault plane, considering normal and shear stress across the fault. This is based on the so-called ubiquitous joint model available as a constitutive relationship in FLAC3D, considering failure along weak planes.
38
 KIGAM applied both finite thickness elements and interface elements to represent the fault mechanical behavior in TOUGH-FLAC. In the case of interface elements, KIGAM developed new coupling routines between TOUGH2 and FLAC3D through fracture mesh aperture changes calculated in FLAC3D.
22


OpenGeoSys (OGS) is an open source finite element simulator
44

,

45
 that was applied by the BGR/UFZ and ENSI research teams, respectively using interface and solid element fault models. BGR/UFZ extended OGS towards the capability of dealing with discrete approaches for the simulation of hydraulic fracturing and fault activation. To this end, lower-dimensional interface (LIE) elements with local enrichments have been implemented in OGS.
23

,

46
 The ENSI research team developed and implemented into OGS an elasto-plastic constitutive model that includes sliding failure along weak planes.
32


Two modeling teams, INER and LBNL, developed models for the fault activation simulations using 3DEC, a code that is based on the Distinct Element Method (DEM). 3DEC handles coupled fluid flow and geomechanics by considering fractures or faults represented by interfaces between deformable blocks.
47

,

48
 Finally, the DynaFrax team applied a three-dimensional (3D) particle flow code (namely, Particle Flow Code 3D, PFC3D) to model fault activation.
49
 This is also based on DEM, with faults formed between particles through variable bond strength and porous media fluid flow.
50
 DynaFrax researchers have in this task extended their particle-flow fault activation modeling to full 3D from previous work in 2D.
51


In all of the above models, whether finite thickness solid elements or interfaces, a Coulomb criterion was used to evaluate shear failure.
52
 As an exception, CNSC considered shear failure using a Drucker-Prager yield criterion.
31
 CNSC calculated permeability evolution based on the elastic and plastic strain normal to the finite thickness fracture plane model, including a damage enhancement factor to enhance the effect of plastic normal strain on fracture permeability.
31
 This fault activation model was implemented in COMSOL Multiphysics
53
 for fully coupled hydromechanical modeling.


4
Step 1 - model inception and benchmarking
A set of well-defined benchmark calculations was first defined to allow for necessary model developments and testing related to fault activation modeling.
17
 As opposed to Steps 2 and 3, here the modeling problem is exactly specified, from the model geometry to the rock properties and constitutive relationships such as the fault permeability as a function of aperture and shear. In contrast, in Steps 2 and 3, modeling teams were expected to move from simple benchmarking to complex conceptual model building and comparison of model results with the field experiments.
In the benchmark, the model geometry was defined to broadly represent the geometry and stress conditions for the subsequent Step 2 fault activation experiment. A 3D model domain was defined to have side-lengths of 20 m and to contain a discontinuity dipping at 65° (Fig. 4
). The initial fluid pressure is set to 0.5 MPa, as estimated from site-specific measurements in the Mont Terri Laboratory. The stress field, somewhat simplified from current site-specific estimates
54
, assumes that the maximum compressive principal stress is exactly vertical at a magnitude of 7.0 MPa, whereas the intermediate principal stress (and maximum horizontal stress) is oriented exactly normal to the strike of the fault at a magnitude of 6.0 MPa. The minimum horizontal stress is parallel to the strike of the fault at a magnitude of 3.3 MPa, but because it is parallel to the fault this stress does not impact the potential for fault activation. For simplicity, the pressure and stress fields are assumed to be uniform over the 20 m cube domain, neglecting gravity. The outer boundaries of the 20 m cube model are defined to be held at constant fluid pressure of 0.5 MPa and mechanically the displacements normal to each boundary are fixed to zero (roller boundaries). The benchmark injection is conducted in controlled pressure steps as shown in Fig. 5
. This injection schedule is the same as was applied in the field during the Step 2 fault activation experiment. A number of monitoring points and profiles were defined for comparison of simulation results between the different teams.
17
 Here we focus comparison on injection rate, deformation at the injection borehole and pore pressure at monitoring point P2 located within the fault plane at 1.5 m radius from the injection point (Fig. 4). Borehole deformations where evaluated from relative anchor displacements corresponding to Fig. 2e and with coordinates of anchors defined in Fig. 4b.
The benchmark host rock properties are listed in Table 2
. These properties are representative of the Mont Terri Laboratory, but simplified in the sense that isotropic and homogeneous properties are assumed over the model domain except for the fault discontinuity. For example, mechanical properties are assumed to be linear elastic and isotropic with a bulk modulus of 5.9 GPa and a shear modulus of 2.3 GPa, which represent average values at the Mont Terri Laboratory.
54

,

55
 Moreover, the host rock is considered impermeable, which is reasonable considering the very low permeability of undisturbed Opalinus Clay and the relative short duration of these experiments.
In these benchmark simulations, a single fault or fracture plane is defined with opening as a result of changes in effective stress assuming a linear elastic normal stiffness, but with a tensile strength of 0 MPa. Two different models or parameter sets are applied for dealing with shear-induced hydraulic aperture changes, and associated changes in fracture transmissivity.

FM1: An elastic (normal) and plastic (shear) opening of the fault is only possible when shear failure occurs.

FM2: An already existing aperture of the fracture, where elastic (normal) opening is allowed from the beginning with propagating pore pressure, while shear (dilatant) opening is only possible when shear failure occurs.
FM1 (Fault Model 1) is defined based on experience with modeling similar fault activation experiments at the Tournemire site in Southern France.
56
 It is a simple model, but one that reasonably reproduced measured responses at the Tournemire site. In this model, as soon as shear- or tensile-failure occur, an induced change in aperture of Δb

hc
 = 28 μm occurs, signifying that an open fault surface has been created. The value of Δb

hc
 = 28 μm comes from the modeling and evaluation of similar field experiments at the Tournemire site.
56

The relations used in FM1 were applied by Guglielmi et al.
56
 at the Tournemire site because measurements indicated substantial permeability increases with shear displacement despite an apparent lack of shear dilation.
The second fault model (FM2) could be viewed as a more conventional hydromechanical fracture model in which hydraulic aperture is equal to the mechanical aperture that in turn depends on opening as a result of reduction in effective stress, fracturing, and shear dilation governed by
